São Domingos Niterói 24210-240 Brazil Ruthenium-copper bimetallic catalysts supported on modified zirconia (m-ZrO2, 2%CaO-ZrO2, 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2) were investigated in hydrogenolysis of glycerol in aqueous solution to produce 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO). Catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption (BET), H2 and CO chemisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Active metallic phase consists of Ru-Cu nanoparticles with average diameter of 1.2 nm when supported on m-ZrO2 and 2%CaO-ZrO2, and larger particles on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2. In all cases, the addition of Cu to the Ru-based catalysts resulted in a decrease in glycerol conversion and increase in selectivity to 1,2-PDO. At 453 K, the best performing catalyst was bimetallic Ru-Cu/m-ZrO2. The catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 showed activity well below expectations, likely due to sulfur poisoning. On the other hand, catalysts supported on 2%CaO-ZrO2 or 10%WO3-ZrO2 showed adequate activity. An increase in 40% in H2 pressure decreased 1,2-PDO selectivity but caused a ten-fold increase in TOF over Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2, to around 0.11 s−1. Cu addition to Ru lead to site blockage, with a beneficial effect on tuning selectivity towards C-O cleavage, and depressing C-C cleavage. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol hydrogenolysis Ruthenium Copper Modified zirconia 1 2-Propanediol 1 Introduction The world has been facing a growing concern about the environmental impacts caused by the consumption of fossil fuels and has been raising several questions about necessary changes in the traditional energy matrix. In order to reduce the dependence on non-renewable energy sources, the use of renewable fuels has been encouraged and is gaining space in the international market. Biodiesel is a renewable fuel derived from biomass and is mostly produced by the transesterification reaction of triglycerides with a low molecular weight alcohol. This reaction is catalyzed by acids and bases and produces a mixture of esters, the biodiesel, and crude glycerol [1]. It is estimated that for every 9 kg of biodiesel produced, 1 kg of glycerol is co-produced [2]. There has been an extreme depreciation on glycerol value due to the growing production of biodiesel, thus causing an increase in the glycerol availability [3]. This decrease in value encouraged the research and production of higher added-value chemicals from glycerol [4], with reliable processes for continuous flow production [5,6]. Glycerol hydrogenolysis is one of the many conversion processes carried out from this chemical and is a new route for the production of several important products for industries, such as 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO), 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) and ethylene glycol (EG) [7]. Propanediols are currently produced mainly by the petrochemical industry. While 1,3-PDO is used mostly in the production of polymers, 1,2-PDO is widely used in paints, medicaments, cosmetics, polyester resins, among others [7–9]. The research on the catalyst for glycerol hydrogenation aims at tuning the composition and nanostructure of surface sites to maximize selectivity and catalytic activity. Several noble (Pt, Pd, Ru) and non-noble (Cu, Ni) metal catalysts have already been tested for this hydrogenolysis. In these experiments, Ru-based catalysts are very active, but selectivity to 1,2-PDO and 1,3-PDO is low as Ru favor C-C cleavage [10–12]. On the other hand, Cu has been evaluated as an interesting alternative in relation to noble metals given its lower cost and greater propensity to favor the C-O cleavage, thus increasing the yield to 1,2-PDO [9,13,14]. In a pioneering work in the field of glycerol hydrogenolysis, Montassier et al. [12] evaluated the use of Cu-Raney and despite obtaining a low conversion of glycerol, the reaction showed a selectivity of 86% to 1,2-PDO for a reaction carried out at 513 K and 3 MPa of hydrogen pressure. Likewise, Durán-Martín et al. [15] obtained conversion close to 10% and selectivity to 1,2-PDO close to 90% by using 2.4 wt%Cu/ZrO2 and 6 wt%Cu/ZrO2 catalysts in reactions carried out at 473 K and 4 MPa of hydrogen pressure for 8 h. Wang et al. [16] studied the effect of metal nature on this reaction. Between Ru, Rh, Pt and Pd catalysts supported on m-ZrO2, Ru-based catalysts showed the best glycerol conversion. Although 2 wt% Ru/m-ZrO2 showed the highest reaction rate, it also exhibited the greatest ability to cleave the C-C bonds. It showed a 22.9% conversion and a 45.7% selectivity to 1,2-PDO in a reaction carried out for 3 h at 473 K and a 6 MPa of hydrogen pressure. Zhou et al. [17] performed a series of reactions at 453 K, 8 MPa of hydrogen pressure for 18 h. By using a 2 wt% Ru/ZrO2 catalyst they obtained 100% of conversion with selectivity of 19.5% to 1,2-PDO. These researchers also evaluated the use of 2 wt% Ru/38 wt% WO3-ZrO2 catalyst and found a 12% conversion and 68.5% selectivity to 1,2-PDO. This discrepancy in these results was mainly justified by the difference in electron density of metal and supports. He et al. [18] evaluated the effect of adding lactic acid on 2 wt% Ru/ZrO2 catalysts. 2 wt% Ru/30 wt% La-ZrO2 catalyst showed the best results with conversion of 60.8% and selectivity of 61% to 1,2-PDO on a reaction carried for 8 h at 463 K and 6 MPa of hydrogen pressure. The acidity on the catalyst surface was considered to be a factor of great influence on catalytic activity. Lee and Moon [19] investigated the use of Ru catalysts in different supports and also concluded that the acidity of the catalyst is directly linked to the conversion of glycerol, as well as to the selectivity to 1,2- PDO. By evaluating the effect of Cu on Ru-based catalysts, Montassier et al. [20] concluded that a deactivation occurred due to copper deposition on the ruthenium surface, which resulted in a drop in activity for the bimetallic catalysts supported on coal when compared to the monometallic Ru catalyst. Jiang et al. [21] also evaluated a series of Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts supported on clay for the glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction. The decrease in Ru/Cu molar ratio also resulted in a decrease in glycerol conversion and a relative increase in selectivity to 1,2-PDO. Optimum catalytic performance was reported for the catalyst with a Ru/Cu ratio of 3/1 under 503 K and 8 MPa of hydrogen pressure. That reaction reached 100% of glycerol conversion with a selectivity of 85% to 1,2-PDO. With the decrease in the Ru/Cu molar ratio, a decrease in glycerol conversion was also observed. Liao et al. [22] observed that the addition of Cu to a Ru catalyst supported on SiO2 led to a 10% drop in glycerol conversion with a 240% increment in selectivity to 1,2-PDO, which was associated with greater cleavage of the C-O bond by increasing the acidity of the catalyst. Liu et al. [23] obtained a satisfying result for 3 wt% Ru-0.19 wt%Cu/ZrO2. This material presented the best catalytic performance in the study and achieved 100% conversion of glycerol with 78.5% selectivity to 1,2-PDO under 453 K and 8 MPa of hydrogen pressure. The authors suggested that there was a joint effect of the two metals on the bimetallic catalyst since this material was more active than monometallic Cu and more selective than monometallic Ru. Salazar et al. [24] investigated a series of Ru and Cu monometallic and Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts supported on TiO2 and suggested that Cu particles act as a diluent of the Ru particles, thus inhibiting the cleavage of C-C bond and the formation of degradation products, in addition to promoting selectivity to 1,2-PDO. In another study presented by the same group, Soares et al. [14] evaluated a series of Ru and Cu monometallic and Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts supported on Al2O3 and ZrO2. Although the bimetallic catalyst supported on Al2O3 showed better conversion results, the 2.5 wt% Ru-2.5 wt%Cu/ZrO2 catalyst showed better selectivity to 1,2-PDO and better TOF. Several supports have already been evaluated for the hydrogenolysis reaction of glycerol, including coal, metal oxides, zeolites, among others [16,25–28]. The relevant results obtained in previous works on Ru-based catalysts supported on ZrO2 encouraged further investigation of the use of Ru and Cu catalysts supported on modified zirconia. As already reported in the literature, the different phases of zirconia have distinct acid characteristics [16], furthermore, the use of modifiers can also interfere with these characteristics, which may result in different catalytic activity and selectivity. Fan et al. [29] investigated the effect of the crystalline phase of the ZrO2 support on the catalytic activity of Pt-WOx catalysts. The catalyst supported on tetragonal zirconia showed a higher glycerol conversion and selectivity to 1,3-propanediol. The difference in activity was attributed to the bigger amount of Brønsted acid sites and the better synergy between the platinum particles to obtain hydrogen atoms on this support. Some published works have evaluated the effect of adding tungsten as a modifier on zirconia [17,30]. In all these works, the catalysts showed high conversion and significant selectivity. In this work, a series of Ru, Cu and Ru-Cu catalysts supported on modified zirconia (m-ZrO2, 2%CaO-ZrO2, 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2) were prepared, characterized, and evaluated for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. Our results helped to further elucidate the role of modifying the ZrO2 support of Ru-Cu catalysts regarding the impact on the catalytic properties in glycerol hydrogenolysis. The effects of temperature and H2 pressures were also tested. Modifications in ZrO2 by including other elements in its structure are paramount for obtaining tuned properties such as acidity and pore size, which impact in great depth catalytic activity. For instance, the presence of reducible oxides within the structure of the support near metal sites may increase reaction rates by favoring hydrogen spillover, such as the case of WO3, which forms HxWO3 bronzes. Another consideration would be increments in acidity by the use of SO4 2- groups. For the aqueous-phase hydrogenolysis of glycerol towards 1,2-PDO, RuCu/ZrO2 catalysts have consistently shown optimal performances, but to the best of our knowledge, there has not been a study considering the effects of the modifications of ZrO2 in these systems. This work provides experimental evidences and clarifies some of the consequences and limits of modifications in the support by introducing CaO as an alkaline promoter, SO4 2- as an acidity enhancer, and WO3 as a reducible oxide prone to hydrogen spillover. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Monometallic Ru, monometallic Cu and bimetallic Ru-Cu catalysts supported on m-ZrO2, 2%CaO-ZrO2, 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2 were synthesized. The loading of each metal was 2.5 wt%. Successive incipient wetness impregnations of Ru and Cu were used to prepare these catalysts. A solution of Ru(NO)(NO3)3 (Sigma-Aldrich) diluted in HNO3, with 0,015 g Ru/mL, was used as precursor for Ru. For Cu, an aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (99% Sigma–Aldrich) was used. The supports were provided by Saint-Gobain NORPRO and Daiichi Kigenso. Before impregnations, supports were calcined at 773 K for 3 h with heating rate of 5 K min−1, except for 10%WO3-ZrO2, which was calcined at 973 K for 3 h. For monometallic catalysts only the desired active metal precursor was added. For bimetallic catalysts, the Ru precursor solution was added first, and then the Cu solution. For full impregnation of Ru, repeated steps of solution addition until pore saturation and subsequent drying at 120 ºC for 12 h were required. A large volume of solution was required for the impregnation of the total amount of Ru as specified. The solution was added dropwise to each of the supports and the mixture was vigorously homogenized between additions. Two Ru impregnations were conducted per day per catalyst. The catalyst was impregnated until pore saturation of the support, after which it was let to dry in an oven for 393 K for 2 h. After drying, a new impregnation was conducted until pore saturation, and a second drying step at 393 K for 15 h (overnight). The process was repeated until all the solution was added to the catalyst. For Cu, a solution with 0.79 mol L−1 was prepared with Cu(NO3)2 in deionized water. For the impregnation of each catalyst 5 mL were used, responsive to the total desired amount of Cu. As in the case of Ru, the solution containing Cu was added dropwise to the support, and the mixture was vigorously homogenized in between additions. After the saturation of the pores, the catalysts were kept in an oven at 393 K for 15 h. After metal impregnation, the catalysts were dried at 393 K for 24 h. No calcination of as-impregnated catalysts was undertaken, to avoid formation of volatile RuO4. 2.2 Catalyst characterization All materials were reduced and passivated before characterization. The reduction was carried at 573 K for 2 h in a stream of pure H2 and the passivation was conducted for 1 h in ambient air. In order to determine surface areas and pore volumes, the BET analysis method was applied employing an ASAP 2010 Micromeritics analyzer to perform N2 physisorption at 77 K. Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed at 523 K for at least 24 h. The X-ray dispersive energy spectroscopy (EDX) technique was performed by using a Shimadzu EDX-700 equipment, with a Rh X-ray tube. For the analyzes, the following operational conditions were applied: 10 mm collimator; vacuum atmosphere; scan ranges Ti-U and Na-Sc, with an irradiation time of 199 and 100 s and tube voltage of 50 and 15 kV, respectively. The X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed in a Rigaku (Miniflex II) diffractometer with a CuKα (1.540 Å) radiation. The XRD patterns were collected with 2θ spanning from 5° to 100° with a step size of 0.02° and integration times of 1 s per step. For Ru/m-ZrO2, Ru-Cu/m-ZrO2, Ru/2%CaO-ZrO2, and Ru-Cu/2%CaO-ZrO2 samples, H2 and CO chemisorption analyses were conducted by flow frontal method in a reactor tube coupled to a quadrupolar mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Vacuum, PrismaTM). Samples of 400 mg were reduced prior to the analysis. For all procedures concerning the frontal method, all gas flows used were 30 mL min−1, and heating rate of 10 K min−1 for all heating. Before reduction, the materials were dried under He flow at 423 K for 30 min. Reduction was performed under H2 flow at 573 K for 1 h, and after reduction He was used once more, at 573 K for 1 h, to clean the surface. Afterwards, heating was turned off and the system was allowed to cool down to around 300 K, still under He flow. For H2 chemisorption, a mixture of 5% hydrogen diluted in argon (5%H2/Ar) was used, and for CO chemisorption, a mixture of 5% carbon monoxide diluted in argon (5%CO/Ar). H2 and CO chemisorption for the remaining materials were performed in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 plus automated adsorption analyzer. The samples analyzed in the Micromeritics ASAP were pretreated at 423 K for 60 min, reduced at 573 K for 180 min under H2 flow and evacuated at 573 K for 60 min. The samples were then cooled to 308 K, the temperature at which the total amount of adsorbed hydrogen was measured. After obtaining the initial adsorption isotherm, the samples were evacuated for 60 min at 308 K and a second adsorption was carried out to determine the amount of reversibly adsorbed hydrogen. In sequence, the CO chemisorption analyzes were performed, in which vacuum cleaning was performed at 573 K for one hour, followed by the analysis at 308 K. Both H2 and CO analyses were performed in a pressure range of 25–200 mmHg with an increase of 25 mmHg. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Escalab 250 XI equipment from Thermo Fischer Scientific, with monochromatic AlKα radiation (1486.6 eV) source and chamber pressure of less than 1×10−8 mbar. For the experiments, 650 µm beam size was used and 100 eV pass energy with 1 eV step size for the exploratory scans were applied. For high resolution scans of the areas of interest, 25 pass energy and 0.05 eV step were carried out. As the Ru 3d and C 1 s peaks overlap, the binding energies for ruthenium were analyzed in the 450–500 eV range (Ru 3p). Likewise, as the W 4 f and Zr 4p peaks also overlap, the 235–270 eV (W 4d) region was chosen for analysis. Gaussian-Lorentzian function was used in the deconvolution of the peaks. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed by using a JEOL JEM-2100F equipment with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The samples were prepared by agitating in an ultrasonic bath a suspension of catalyst and ethanol for 10 min and then applying drops of the suspension to a Cu or a Mo grid with C film. The average metal particle sizes were estimated by using the ImageJ software. At least 200 particles were counted to obtain each distribution histogram. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements Glycerol hydrogenolysis reactions were carried out in a 300 mL stainless steel batch reactor (Parr 4848), in which 1.20 g of catalyst and 150 g of 10 wt% glycerol aqueous solution were charged. Aqueous glycerol solutions were prepared using bi-distilled glycerin with 99.5% purity from VETEC Química (from Sigma-Aldrich group). All catalysts used in the reaction tests were previously reduced under H2 in a separate continuous gas flow unit. The reduction process began with drying under 30 mL min−1 of He flow at a heating rate of 10 K min−1 until 423 K was reached and maintained for 30 min. After drying the system would be let to cool under still under He flow until 303 K. After drying, reduction took place under 30 mL min−1 of H2 flow at a heating rate of 5 K min−1 until 573 K was reached and maintained for 3 h. The catalyst was then let to cool still under H2 until 298 K, when the gas then switched to back to He (30 mL min−1) and a cooling bath of ice and liquid nitrogen decreased the temperature below 273 K for 5 min, in order to establish a low temperature. Passivation of the catalysts occurred after the reactor was disconnected from the reduction unit and exposed to air for 1 h while still under sub-freeze temperatures. The reactor was loaded with the glycerol solution and the appropriate amount of catalyst then a purge was conducted three times with N2 to remove any residual air. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was activated in situ at room temperature and initial hydrogen manometric pressure of 2.5 MPa for 1 h. All pressure values reported in this work for the catalytic activity measurements refer to gauge pressure. During the reaction, the temperature was kept at 453 K or at 473 K, the H2 initial pressure at 293 K was 2.5 MPa, and the stirring rate was 500 rpm. After reaction, the reactor was depressurized and the liquid products were separated from the catalyst by centrifugation. The liquid phase was analyzed and the products identified by a GC-MS (Shimadzu, GCMS-QP2010S) equipped with a SupelcoWax capillary column. 1-Butanol was used as the internal standard for quantitative calculation. For the measurement of reaction rates and TOF, four liquid samples of approximately 2 mL were taken from the reactor every 30 min, for the first 2 h of the catalytic tests. The gas phase was not analyzed in this work. Glycerol conversion, TOF and liquid product selectivity were calculated using the following equations: Conversion ( % ) = total molar quantity of carbons in the products formed ( mol ) total molar quantity of carbons at the end of the reaction ( mol ) × 100 TOF ( s − 1 ) = total molar quantity of formed products ( mol ) total molar quantity of metal on the surface ( mol ) × reaction time ( s ) Selectivity % = total molar quantity of carbons in the product i ( mol ) total molar quantity of carbons in the products formed ( mol ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Surface areas, pore volumes and average pore diameters of the supports and their catalysts are shown in Table 1. The addition of CaO, SO4 and WO3 modifiers to zirconia was beneficial to the specific surface area and stabilizes the pore volume and the average pore diameter. All materials can be classified as mesoporous, since their average pore diameter is within the range of 2–50 nm [31]. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffractograms for all materials studied. Pristine m-ZrO2 and respective supported catalysts showed only the monoclinic zirconia crystal phase, while 2%CaO-ZrO2 and respective supported catalysts showed only the tetragonal crystal phase. However, both phases were detected in the materials supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2. Although the two phases of zirconia were observed in the diffractograms of the catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2, the decrease in the tetragonal phase was visible in all catalysts when compared to their supports. No peaks for Ru0, RuOx, Cu0 and CuO were detected in the diffractograms, likely due to the small amount of impregnated metals and possible overlap of the characteristic peaks of the supports. Table 2 shows the results for EDX analyses, which were similar to the expected values for nominal composition. Sulfur was not identified by EDX analysis, likely due to the proximity of Kα and Kβ lines from S to the Lγ line from Zr. All catalysts containing Ru showed slightly higher content than expected, which could be due to contributions from the lines from Rh from the X-ray tube. Monometallic Cu catalysts and the other bimetallic catalysts present values similar to nominal, which indicates a successful impregnation. The principal impurity identified was the element Hf, which is commonly found with ZrO2 regularly at 1–3%wt, and can not be easily separated, due to the similarity between the atomic properties of Zr and Hf (radius of 1.45 Å and 1.44 Å, respectively, and electronic distributions 4d25 s2 and 5d26 s2, respectively [32,33]. Table 3 shows molar Cu/Ru ratio results measured by XPS. Values of molar Cu/Ru ratios measured by XPS are all above nominal, which may indicate an enrichment of Cu particles on the surface of bimetallic particles [24]. Results measured by EDX, on the other hand, are bellow the nominal reference (Cu/Ru = 1.25 for Ru-Cu/3%SO4-ZrO2, and Cu/Ru = 1.22 for Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2). These results indicate that only part of the Cu utilized in the synthesis remained in the final catalyst. Nonetheless, the available Cu from impregnation is largely present on the surface the catalyst, likely on top of Ru, for all catalysts, with special mention to Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2, with the highest Cu/Ru ratio. Table 3 also presents the results for binding energy of Ru 3p3/2 and Cu 2p3/2 species. Monometallic and bimetallic catalysts supported on m-ZrO2 and 2%CaO-ZrO2 showed very close binding energy values, which may indicate that there were not any strong electronic interactions between these metals in the bimetallic catalysts [24]. Besides, the catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2 showed different binding energies between the monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. As well as the catalysts supported on m-ZrO2 and 2%CaO-ZrO2, the bimetallic catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2 presented binding energies according to the Ru4 + oxidation state, whereas the monometallic catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2 showed binding energies according to the Ru0 oxidation state [34]. The results for H2 and CO chemisorption, average metal particle diameter calculated from CO chemisorption (dCO) and TEM (dTEM), as well as the surface average diameter determined by TEM are shown in Table 4. It was assumed that chemisorption occurred only on ruthenium surface atoms, considering the adsorption as null on copper particles. This methodology was adopted due to the great physical adsorption and the uncertainty in the CO/Cu stoichiometry [35] and because it is known that Cu does not adsorb H2 at room temperature [36]. It is useful to discuss the results in light of some literature. Reference studies on Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts reveal that addition of Cu to Ru decreases considerably the ability to chemisorb, and that epitaxial growth over Ru(0001) forms Cu(111) faces, which chemisorb poorly both H and CO [37,38]. Monometallic Ru readily causes hydrogen dissociative chemisorption or CO chemisorption, depending on site availability. Monometallic Cu adsorbs poorly both probe species, which implies that only Ru atoms should be considered as adsorbents in calculations. Therefore, Cu atoms block Ru atoms when epitaxy occurs, decreasing chemisorption in Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts in comparison with monometallic Ru catalysts. Successive impregnation is superior to co-impregnation as a synthesis method for Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts regarding H2 uptake, since the former likely renders particles that reproduce Cu structures atop of Ru structures as in the epitaxy growth, while the latter, at low Cu content, may form alloys [39,40]. In view of this, H and CO uptakes decrease with increasing Cu content on bimetallic catalysts, as observed for all catalysts in this work. Moreover, for submonolayer surfaces of Cu, two-dimensional monolayer ‘island’ formation should be expected, as opposed to the formation of three-dimensional Cu clusters [41]. Blockage from a metal differs from poisoning not only for the milder effect in activity decrease, but also because it may tune ensemble properties, as the case of possible hydrogen spillover from Ru sites to Cu sites at low temperature on bimetallic Ru-Cu surfaces [42–44]. Besides the chemisorption dependence on the bimetallic particles themselves, the results point to the fact that the metal-support interaction plays a pivotal role in H2 and CO uptake, since varying the support’s composition dramatically changes chemisorption. It has been proposed that perturbations are more pervasive to dissociative than associative adsorption, affecting H2 more than CO chemisorption [38]. These perturbations may be the cause for the varying performance of the SO4-ZrO2 support, as evidence of sulfur poisoning, since the monometallic Ru catalyst shows the same H2 uptake as the bimetallic catalyst on SO4-ZrO2 support. Although both probe species present overall decreased uptake, it is clear that poisoning affects H2 chemisorption much more strongly than CO chemisorption. Experiments have demonstrated that sulfate from the ZrO2 support causes Ru sulfur-poisoning, decreasing catalyst activity [45]. Although the chemisorption of CO may be bridged or on top of active atoms on Ru-nanoparticles, it does not involve breaking the C–O bond. It is also a known fact that under certain conditions, ruthenium forms carbonyl coordination compounds with CO, with general formula Rux(CO)y, e.g. Ru(CO)5 [46]. The occurrence of coordination compounds is not expected, but certain atoms on the particle’s surface should be able to chemisorb more than one CO molecule, with local CO/Ru ratios greater than 1. On the other hand, H2 chemisorption is a dissociative adsorption, in which the expected H2:Ru ratio follows the stoichiometry of 1:2 (H2 and CO adsorption isotherms are available in ESI). For the other supports, CO/Ru ratios decrease more sharply than the H/Ru ratios, by the addition of Cu (Table 4). The WO3-ZrO2 support shows unexpected performance for CO chemisorption, and indicates possible spillover, since particle formation precludes the availability of all impregnated Ru atoms to be at the surface. Fig. 2 shows the TEM micrographs and the respective diameter size distribution for Ru/m-ZrO2 and Ru/2%CaO-ZrO2. In these and the bimetallic catalysts Ru formed relatively small nanoparticles with average sizes less than 2 nm. In addition, average surface particle diameters were close to those measured directly by TEM for all catalysts. The values of Ru particle diameters approximated by chemisorption were greater than the surface particle diameters and those measured by TEM in all materials, as shown in Table 4, although they can be considered as in the same order of magnitude. As already explained, when estimating the particle size by chemisorption there is a possibility of errors due to Cu deposition on Ru surface. It was difficult to determine the diameter of the Ru particles from the TEM micrographs of the catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2 due to agglomeration of the Ru particles. STEM micrographs of Ru/3%SO4-ZrO2 and Ru/10%WO3-ZrO2 catalysts and the elemental mapping analyses by EDX are shown in Fig. 3. For both catalysts, the darker spots in the images are confirmed as Ru clusters and the lighter particles are the zirconia supports, as indicated by the EDX mapping results. Agglomeration of Ru particles occurred in these catalysts. 3.2 Glycerol hydrogenolysis The results of glycerol conversion and selectivity are shown in Table 5, while Figs. 4 and 5 show the concentration profile for glycerol and 1,2-PDO for some of the catalysts. The main products obtained by the hydrogenolysis of glycerol were 1,2-PDO, EG, 1-PrOH, 1,3-PDO, 2-PrOH and methanol. Although the addition of Cu to the Ru-based catalysts increased selectivity for 1,2-PDO in all cases, this addition also caused a drop in activity when compared to Ru monometallic catalysts. Monometallic catalysts with 2.5%Cu were also tested for the studied supports. All of them had a conversion lower than 1%, this result is in agreement with previously published works [14,47]. At 453 K, 2.5 MPa of initial hydrogen pressure and reaction time of 12 h, the monometallic catalyst Ru/m-ZrO2 showed the best conversion (Table 4). Although the crystalline phase of zirconia is not the same in each catalyst, they showed very similar conversions and selectivity, excluding the catalyst supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2, which did not show significant activity under the tested conditions. Previous studies have reported a linear relationship between acidity and glycerol conversion [19,48]. However, due to the low activity found in this work, it was concluded that a catalyst poisoning by sulfur may have occurred in the catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2, which is consistent with the chemisorption results. This harmful interaction of sulfur and ruthenium has also been reported previously for the hydrogenolysis reaction. Kusunoki et al. [49] evaluated that the addition of H2SO4 in the catalytic system decreased ruthenium functionality. Maris et al. [50] reported on the possibility of adsorbed sulfur change the electronic surface of ruthenium and favor a higher energy reaction route. Another factor that may have influenced the low conversion is the possible formation of ruthenium clusters, taking into account the TEM micrographs and the low H/Ru ratio in these catalysts. In addition, by the XPS characterization was also possible to verify that the catalysts supported on sulfated zirconia had a less enriched ruthenium surface. Under the same reaction conditions, monometallic and bimetallic catalysts supported on 2%CaO-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2 showed very close conversion values. The catalysts supported on 2%CaO-ZrO2, however, showed greater selectivity for 1,2-PDO. Despite this lower selectivity for 1,2-PDO, the monometallic and bimetallic catalysts supported in 10%WO3-ZrO2 showed a higher selectivity for 1,3-PDO than all the other tested catalysts, 10% and 6% respectively. Despite having a much lower CO adsorption capacity than the other catalysts (Table 4), Ru-Cu/2% CaO-ZrO2 showed higher conversion than the catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and similar conversion to Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2. Thus, it can be assumed that other factors were more relevant to the catalytic activity. In a previously work by Soares et al.[14], catalysts supported on alumina and zirconia were studied for glycerol hydrogenolysis under 453 K, 2.5 MPa of initial hydrogen pressure and a 20% g/g glycerol solution. 2.5 wt%Ru/Al2O3 catalyst showed 33% conversion and 42% selectivity for 1,2-PDO, while 2.5 wt%Ru-2.5 wt%Cu/Al2O3 showed 21% conversion and 92% selectivity. While 2.5 wt%Ru/ZrO2 and 2.5 wt%Ru-2.5 wt%Cu/ZrO2 showed 30% and 14% conversion with 70% and 100% selectivity for 1,2-PDO respectively. The zirconia systems exhibited conversions similar to those found in the present study, however the selectivities were lower in this work. As it can be seen in Table 5, in all cases the TOF experienced a small decrease with the addition of Cu in the catalysts, which may show a blockage of Ru sites by these particles. Although gas-phase products are relevant for many aqueous-phase hydrogenolysis reactions, carbon balance from chromatograms, and total mass balances considering the feed mass, the final mass and the mass of samples for kinetics show that the amount of gas products is negligible for the conditions of the tests. Table 6 shows the iso-conversion results for the tested catalysts. The results presented in this table confirm the trend of high selectivity for 1,2-PDO in Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts, while Ru monometallic catalysts have showed lower selectivity for 1,2-PDO. For conversions close to 5%, monometallic catalysts showed selectivity close to 50%, while bimetallic catalysts showed selectivity close to 80%. In all tests performed, the presence of acetol was not detected, while in reactions with greater conversion the presence of methanol was confirmed. These results suggest the dehydrogenation-dehydration-hydrogenation mechanism initially proposed by Montassier et al. [20,25] as the probable mechanism for the reactions. In this mechanism, glycerol dehydrogenation occurs in metallic sites for the glyceraldehyde intermediate followed by dehydration to 2-hydroxy-acrolein and the consequent hydrogenation to 1,2-propanediol. 3.2.1 The effect of temperature Table 7 shows the effect of temperature on conversion and selectivity. In all cases there was an increase in glycerol conversion with a temperature change from 453 K to 473 K, as expected. All catalysts analyzed had their TOFs doubled or tripled with the increase in temperature and all monometallic catalysts showed TOF superior to their respective bimetallic catalysts. At higher temperature (473 K) the selectivity for 1,2-PDO in the reactions with Ru/3%SO4-ZrO2 and Ru-Cu/3%SO4-ZrO2 was high, although the conversion remained much lower than the observed in the other tested materials. It is worth to highlight that despite Ru/3%SO4-ZrO2 and Ru-Cu/SO4-ZrO2 showed lower conversions than the other catalysts, their TOF values were similar. Liu et al. [23] reported a drop in selectivity for 1,2-PDO with an increase in reaction temperature from 453 K to 473 K, not observed in this work. In fact, Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2 showed a small increase in selectivity. However, the systems at 473 K showed a drop in selectivity for 1,3-PDO. The increase in conversion and selectivity for 1,2-PDO indicates that the reaction temperature of 473 K was considered adequate for producing 1,2-PDO with the tested catalyst. 3.2.2 The effect of hydrogen pressure To assess the pressure effect on the hydrogenolysis of glycerol, two additional tests were performed. Table 8 shows these results. Ru/10%WO3-ZrO2 was tested again under similar conditions to the one already presented, but the system pressure was kept constant throughout the process. This system had a conversion 13% higher than the system without the addition of new H2. Despite being a satisfactory result, this was below expectations as there was a suspicion of reaction limitation due to the availability of H2 in the system. Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2 was also tested at a constant higher pressure (3.4 MPa). This reaction showed conversion and reaction frequency 5 and 10 times bigger than the reaction with addition of H2 only at the beginning. Despite the large increase in glycerol conversion, there was also an inverse effect on selectivity for 1,2-PDO, with a 37% drop in selectivity for 1,2-PDO and a proportional increase in selectivity for 1-PrOH. The expectation of high selectivity for 1,2-PDO with the addition of Cu to the Ru-based catalyst was not met in this case. Although the addition of H2 in the system during the reaction did not cause major changes in the results with Ru/10%WO3-ZrO2, this addition of H2 plus the increase of pressure in the reaction using Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2 generated a significant increase in conversion and in the TOF. For a 40% increase in pressure, there was a ten-fold increase in TOF. Thus, the reaction kinetics is improved with the increase in hydrogen concentration. In view of the product distribution, it is reasonable to assume EG comes from the cleavage of the C-CH3 bond in 1,2-PDO, since the concentration of methanol is significantly lower than the concentration of EG in the products. This result indicates that decreased 1,2-PDO selectivity by increased H2 pressure is a consequence of consecutive hydrogenolysis of 1,2-PDO, caused by hydrogen availability on catalyst surface. This higher hydrogen availability is attributed to the formation of HxWO3 bronzes from the reduction of WO3. The presence of a noble metal such as Ru catalyzes the reduction toward HxWO3 at relatively low temperatures in the presence of hydrogen. HxWO3 at the vicinity of Ru metallic sites could then contribute as a hydrogen donor to adsorbed molecules. Therefore, EG production is likely due to parallel C-C hydrogenolysis reactions with glycerol or with 1,2-PDO, but more substantially from the latter. Moreover, the enhanced activity from higher H2 pressures leads to consecutive hydrogenolysis reactions, as seen in the formation of 1-PrOH. 3.2.3 Deactivation and catalyst recycle Exploratory recycle experiments were performed as part of this study, and should be considered with caution. Table 9 presents the recycling results for the catalysts supported on m-ZrO2, 2%CaO-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2. The results for the catalysts supported on 10%WO3-ZrO2 showed that there was no significant deactivation or catalytic poisoning after the first use, however in both cases there was a small drop in selectivity for 1,2-PDO. A previous work by this group presented these same trends under a Ru/ZrO2 catalyst [14]. Although there was a small drop in selectivity for 1,2-PDO, both reuse reactions led to small increase in selectivity for 1,3-PDO. The reclycle reaction with Ru-Cu/WO3-ZrO2 showed the best selectivity for 1,3-PDO at 473 K. On the other hand, the catalysts supported on m-ZrO2 and 2%Cao-ZrO2 presented a deactivation after the first use. This may have occurred due to the adsorption of some carbon source in the Ru sites in an irreversible way, leading to deactivation by poisoning [24]. 4 Conclusion Bimetallic catalysts of copper and ruthenium supported on modified zirconia show promise as catalysts for aqueous-phase hydrogenolysis reactions. At 5% conversion, all bimetallic Ru-Cu catalysts supported on modified ZrO2 show superior selectivity toward 1,2-PDO than monometallic Ru catalysts. This resukt shows a compromise between highly selective but poorly active Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, and highly active but poorly selective Ru/ZrO2 catalysts. There is still room for investigations on Ru/Cu ratios and selection of best supports. The addition of 2%CaO drastically changes the structure of ZrO2 crystals, and serves as the best support for H chemisorption, but with no corresponding drastic change in activity or selectivity, serving as evidence for other effects at play (acidity, electronic effects, etc.). After reduction, SO4-ZrO2 support causes sulfur poisoning of active metal sites. This effect is much greater towards hydrogen uptake than carbon monoxide uptake, and has direct negative impact on the activity toward the aqueous-phase hydrogenolysis reaction. Ru-Cu/m-ZrO2 shows the highest selectivity toward 1,2-PDO, and best performance at 453 K. Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2 also shows adequate performance, especially considering recycling, and the increment in TOF when the H2 pressure is increased. The successive addition of Cu to Ru formed copper-rich particles on the surface of the catalyst (as seen in XPS Cu/Ru ratios). This leads to site blockage, with a beneficial effect on tuning selectivity towards C-O cleavage, and depressing C-C cleavage, as seen in the product distribution, where 1-PrOH is favored instead of EG in consecutive hydrogenolysis reactions for higher H2 pressure. coredata.dc:description: Ruthenium-copper bimetallic catalysts supported on modified zirconia (m-ZrO2, 2%CaO-ZrO2, 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2) were investigated in hydrogenolysis of glycerol in aqueous solution to produce 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO). Catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption (BET), H2 and CO chemisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Active metallic phase consists of Ru-Cu nanoparticles with average diameter of 1.2 nm when supported on m-ZrO2 and 2%CaO-ZrO2, and larger particles on 3%SO4-ZrO2 and 10%WO3-ZrO2. In all cases, the addition of Cu to the Ru-based catalysts resulted in a decrease in glycerol conversion and increase in selectivity to 1,2-PDO. At 453 K, the best performing catalyst was bimetallic Ru-Cu/m-ZrO2. The catalysts supported on 3%SO4-ZrO2 showed activity well below expectations, likely due to sulfur poisoning. On the other hand, catalysts supported on 2%CaO-ZrO2 or 10%WO3-ZrO2 showed adequate activity. An increase in 40% in H2 pressure decreased 1,2-PDO selectivity but caused a ten-fold increase in TOF over Ru-Cu/10%WO3-ZrO2, to around 0.11 s−1. Cu addition to Ru lead to site blockage, with a beneficial effect on tuning selectivity towards C-O cleavage, and depressing C-C cleavage.
coredata.dc:title: Glycerol hydrogenolysis over Ru-Cu bimetallic catalysts supported on modified zirconias
